frameDefinitions: An Experiencer desires that an Event occur.
An Accused individual is deemed by a (usually implicit) Judge to be involved (or not) in a Misdeed.
An Experiencer feels bad about a choice, an Action, or a failure to do something, which they now consider to have been a mistake or wrong.
The words in this frame describe the process of making amends for some (wrongful) action (the Injury) committed by the Wrongdoer.
In this frame an Evaluee is described by a (usually implicit) Judge with respect to the morality or rightness of his or her Behavior.
In this frame an Offense is described in terms of the legal or other punishing action that can be taken in response to the offense.
frameExamples: I only <t>wanted</t> one piece of candy.
I am <t>innocent</t> of this crime and so is James Griffiths .
Smithers did not <t>repent</t> of his crime.
That was very <t>righteous</t> of you to help him.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Experiencer</fen> is the person (or sentient being) who wishes for the <fen>Event</fen> to occur.
The change that the <fen>Experiencer</fen> would like to see.
This is the entity that the <fen>Experiencer</fen> wishes to be affected by some <fen>Event</fen>.
The <fen>Location_of_event</fen> is the place involved in the desired <fen>Event</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> is when the <fen>Experiencer</fen> desires something.
Where the event takes place.  Note that this role is of extremely rare occurrence in this frame.
This is the person who is accused of a  <fen>Misdeed</fen>.
The wrongful act which  the <fen>Accused</fen> was purportedly involved in.
The role <fen>Experiencer</fen> indicates the person who experiences the emotion about their prior action.
The role <fen>Action</fen> marks expressions that indicate a prior action that the <fen>Experiencer</fen> has come to feel bad about.
The role <fen>Expressor</fen> marks expressions that indicate a gesture or body part which is displaying the <fen>Emotional_state</fen> of the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.
The role <fen>Emotional_state</fen> is modified by an adjective  that indicates the <fen>Experiencer</fen> is contrite.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the <fen>Experiencer</fen> or the <fen>Expressor</fen> is contrite.
The <fen>Injured_party</fen> was affected by some previous wrongful act of the <fen>Wrongdoer</fen> and who should benefit from the reparations.
The <fen>Injury</fen> is the injurious action that  the <fen>Wrongdoer</fen> committed against the <fen>Injured_party</fen>.  Although conceptually present, this role need not always be realized.
The <fen>Wrongdoer</fen> makes amends to the <fen>Injured_party</fen> for the <fen>Injury</fen>.
The <fen>Benefiting_action</fen> is performed by the <fen>Wrongdoer</fen> to make amends.
<fen>Gift</fen> identifies the entity that the <fen>Wrongdoer</fen> gives to the <fen>Injured_party</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when amends are made.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Wrongdoer</fen> makes amends.
This is the person whose <fen>Behavior</fen> is being judged with respect to its morality.
The assessment of the <fen>Evaluee</fen> is based on his or her <fen>Behavior</fen>.
The <fen>Expressor</fen> is the body part or action by a body part which is the basis of the evaluation of morality.
The <fen>Offense</fen> is the action, crime, or event which is described in terms of what legal or punishing action can be taken against the offender.
listRoleExamples: I want that box <fex>on top of the other one</fex>.
Oh, so <fex>now</fex> you want to go to the zoo!
<fex>In the car</fex> I had desired nothing more than to get here, but now that I'm here...
<fex>Frank Quattrone</fex> is found guilty of obstructing federal investigations
Cambridge woman says she's innocent <fex>of fraud</fex>.
They confessed and repented <fex>their actions against the Soviet Union</fex>.
Martha had a guilty <fex>conscience</fex> after selling inferior merchandise.
You can never make amends <fex>to Susan</fex> for standing her up.
Wyelander sought reparations <fex>for the brutal murder of his nephew</fex>.
How  can <fex>I</fex> make it up to you?
Between friends, amends can be made <fex>by apologizing</fex>.
He made it up to her <fex>with a bouquet of flowers</fex>.
He made amends to her <fex>that very afternoon</fex>.
Restitution was given <fex>in Milan</fex> with the Treaty of Abiselle.
It was honorable <fex>of Jackie</fex> to give up the position.
<fex>Accepting that money</fex> was immoral of Lindsay.
His face twisted into an evil <fex>grin</fex>
